body: @fontiano that’s pretty funny. You could try yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt, it’s a higher mAP model. See readme map section.
@FranciscoReveriano —classes 0 means that detect.py will only output class 0 detections, ie only people in this case.

@fontiano another option you could try is disabling multi-class nms. This outputs any class above threshold for a given anchor, rather than just the highest class. If your object is returning cat and person both above threshold (but only visualizing the person box because of your --classes 0 argument), then this may help.

add `multi_cls=False` here:
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/764514e44da961b4f5a8df59a67f1a9496af9a71/detect.py#L90-L92

Default is `True`:
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/764514e44da961b4f5a8df59a67f1a9496af9a71/utils/utils.py#L504

rename.from: Need Help with pre-trained weigths and some images
rename.to: Zoneminder output inference detecting cat as person

body:
> @fontiano another option you could try is disabling multi-class nms. This outputs any class above threshold for a given anchor, rather than just the highest class. If your object is returning cat and person both above threshold (but only visualizing the person box because of your --classes 0 argument), then this may help.
> 
> add `multi_cls=False` here:
> https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/764514e44da961b4f5a8df59a67f1a9496af9a71/detect.py#L90-L92
> 
> Default is `True`:
> https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/764514e44da961b4f5a8df59a67f1a9496af9a71/utils/utils.py#L504

Ok, I added that line and the problem was fixed for the first image.

Unfortunately the other 3 images of that little cat are still recognized as people.

I used the script "download_yolov3_weights.sh" to download .pt weights but:
1) can't find yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt - found it!
2) using yolov3.pt and yolov3-spp-pt did not "fixed" my problem

> @fontiano that’s pretty funny. You could try yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt, it’s a higher mAP model. See readme map section.

It seems that using that model did the trick:
python3 detect.py --device cpu --cfg cfg/yolov3-spp.cfg --weights weights/yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt --conf-thres 0.70 --source /errori/471.jpg

I will try the new model and check its behavior with the other cameras. Obviously I will give you the results in a few days.

Last doubt:
when i use the "yolov3-spp-ultralitycs.pt" template which config file should i use? It seems that the correct one is the "yolov3-spp.cfg"

In the meantime, thank you!

@fontiano hmmm that's good news. Yes, yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt corresponds to yolov3-spp.cfg.

Remember though the mAP@0.5 on that model is about 0.62 at 608 though, not 1.00, so you will always get a few FPs etc.

> @fontiano hmmm that's good news. Yes, yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt corresponds to yolov3-spp.cfg.
> 
> Remember though the mAP@0.5 on that model is about 0.62 at 608 though, not 1.00, so you will always get a few FPs etc.

Ok.
When I do the tests I always have to open the images to check the recognition percentage. Is there any way to add that percentage to the console's output logs?

@fontiano yes, you would have to modify the printed string `s` here:
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/84371f68117cae975eabfa78cdf8a2aa1b78e4ba/detect.py#L105-L126

After about 3 days of use I had 2 other false positives (a black cat and the wake of an insect that intersected with the trees). I solved it by making a double scan: the first scan with the model yolov3.pt (imgsize 608, thres 0.70) and the second with ssp-ultralytics (imgsize 608, thres 0.70).

It is now about 7 days since I have had false positives using the double scan without losing too many doubtful events.

I have to evaluate whether to increase the number of frames to be analyzed or whether to change the combination of the models used. For now this is the best setting. I will give you updates in another 10 days.

@fontiano ah that's interesting. You are using the ensemble approach then, with an AND requirement.

We had a request from someone else for mutli-scale inference (sometimes referred to as test-time inference). The idea would be to run inference at several scales (using the same model), and then return the merged result. This might work for you too.

FP reduction is one of the main challenge in many production systems. I think for video analysis you may really need to add a time dimension to your code, for example to require >3 detections within a trailing time window before any of them are saved, because an actual detection should be repeatable, whereas an FP may tend to be more transient in nature.

One way to do this would be to reshape your video streams, instead of streaming one image at a time, batch 30 frames togethor and use logic to only save detections that occur several times in the same batch.
